Keith_Stegall:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter and record producer}} {{Use American English|date=December 2022}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Keith Stegall | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Robert Keith Stegall{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=401|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1955|11|01}} | origin = [[Wichita Falls, Texas]], United States | instrument = Vocals

[[Epic Records|Epic]]
[[Mercury Records|Mercury]] | website = {{URL|www.keithstegall.com}} }} '''Robert Keith Stegall''' (born November 1, 1955{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p128262/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Keith Stegall biography |access-date=January 7, 2008 |last=Huey |first=Steve |work=[[Allmusic]]}}) is an American [[country music]] recording artist and record producer. Active since 1980, Stegall has recorded two major-label studio albums: 1985's ''Keith Stegall'' and 1996's ''Passages'', although he is mainly known for his production work. ==Musical career== Robert Keith Stegall was born in [[Wichita Falls, Texas]], in 1955. He performed in local bands, spent a short time in northwestern Louisiana (in the mid-1970s) where he operated a small-time music recording business, then moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], at the persuasion of [[Kris Kristofferson]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.rama-info.com/home/producers/third/bio2_text.html |title=Keith Stegall |access-date=April 27, 2013 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20130630055830/http://www.rama-info.com/home/producers/third/bio2_text.html |archive-date=June 30, 2013 |url-status=dead }} Stegall charted thirteen singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, with the highest-peaking being 1985's "Pretty Lady", a No. 10 hit. Starting in the late 1980s, Stegall has been active primarily as a record producer for several recording acts, most notably [[Alan Jackson]], [[George Jones]], [[Zac Brown Band]], and [[Clay Walker]]. Stegall has also written several of Jackson's singles, as well as [[George Strait]]'s Number one hit "[[I Hate Everything (song)|I Hate Everything]]" and [[Dr. Hook]]'s "[[Sexy Eyes (Dr. Hook song)|Sexy Eyes]]". In 2008, Stegall co-founded the label [[Bigger Picture Music Group]].{{Cite web |url=http://biggerpicturegroup.com/updates/news/producer%E2%80%99s-chair-keith-stegall-189 |title=News: The Producer's Chair: Keith Stegall | Bigger Picture Group Artist Services |access-date=May 9, 2014 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20140509040502/http://biggerpicturegroup.com/updates/news/producer%E2%80%99s-chair-keith-stegall-189 |archive-date=May 9, 2014 |url-status=dead }} The label closed in 2014. In 2016, Stegall launched a Nashville-based production, management, and publishing firm, Dreamlined Entertainment Group, with Scott Miller of Miller Investment Management.{{cite web | date=February 1, 2016 | title=Keith Stegall Launches Dreamlined Entertainment Group | url=https://musicrow.com/2016/02/keith-stegall-launches-dreamlined-entertainment-group/ | work=Jessica Nicholson }} In October 2017, Fangate Music, a label run by Australian country music promoter Rob Potts, in conjunction with [[Sony Music Australia]], announced their partnership with Stegall's Dreamlined Entertainment Group.{{cite web | date=October 17, 2017 | title=Sony Music Australia & Fangate Music partner with Dreamlined Entertainment | url=https://www.theindustryobserver.com.au/sony-fangate-dreamlined-entertainment/ | work=Tyler Jenke }} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:10em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Album details ! colspan="1"| Peak positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="65"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]] |- ! scope="row"| ''Keith Stegall'' | * Release date: April 10, 1985 * Label: Epic Records | 45 |- ! scope="row"| ''Passages'' | * Release date: February 27, 1996 * Label: Mercury Nashville | — |- | colspan="3" style="font-size:8pt"| "—" denotes releases that did not chart |- |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:22em;"| Single ! colspan="2"| Peak chart
